learning_outcomes.description: Outline the biology of plant-microbe & insect interactions
Outline the biology of plant interactions with their environment
Identify biotechnology applications of plant interactions
Critically evaluate literature in plant interactions and identify gaps in the literature
Demonstrate core practical skills in plant biology using laboratory and non-laboratory techniques todetermin both qualitative and quantitative outcomes.

assessments.assessment_title: Plant Interactions Annotated Bibliography and Research Gaps
assessments.task_description:
You will choose one topic to explore in depth from the list of supplied topics relating to plant, microbe, insect, and environment interactions. Within this topic, you will then develop an annotated bibliography, with each one having a summary together with an evaluation of the academic metrics to attest to its relevance in the topic. Following this, you will use your knowledge of this topic to identify gaps in the literature that would be a useful research topic to build on existing knowledge. Students must have a distinct topic from the list provided or identify their own for approval by the course coordinators. The topics must be chosen by the end of week 2 or a topic will be assigned.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your Assessment task, in Blackboard, via the Turnitin link by the submission deadline. You should also retain an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit. Legal Declaration By submitting your work via this website, you formally declare that:

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.category: Notebook/ Logbook, Participation/ Student contribution, Practical/ Demonstration, Project, Quiz
assessments.task_description:
During the practical component of this course, you will isolate and identify a novel bacterium that can form a symbiosis with a legume using physiological, molecular, microbiological and bioinformatic approaches. In each class, you will complete an assessment that will be delivered by blackboard and/or demonstrate a laboratory technique by the end of each practical session. Blackboard assessment may include a mix of multiple choice questions, short answer questions or uploading results from the practical session. Answers for questions may come from any of the practical classes, lectures, blackboard content or literature sources identified independently.

Attendance for the practical classes is mandatory to complete each sequential assessment. Due to the format of the assessment being completed during the practical session where these activities are unable to be re-produced, extensions cannot be granted assessments in Prac 1, 2, 3 and 5 assessment items. For Prac 4 - Skill Assessment and Prac 6 - Quiz and results submission, extensions can be granted for approved students. For prac 4 and 6 only, students who are unable to attend the practical for reasons beyond their control will need to complete the ‘Absence from Practical’ form.

Students must be in attendance of at least 4 of the 6 practical classes to meet the Learning Objectives of this Assessment.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

Absence from a Practical Session

If you are unable to complete your timetabled practical session because of circumstances beyond your control (e.g., illness) you must submit a practical absence request immediately accompanied by acceptable supporting documentation.

 A list of acceptable reasons and required supporting documentation is found at https://my.uq.edu.au/information-and-services/manage-my-program/exams-and-assessment/applying-assessment-extension?p=1#1  

Your request must be submitted prior to or on the day of the missed practical. The submission link can be found in the Learning Resources (Blackboard Original) or Course Resources (Blackboard Ultra) folder in your course Blackboard site.

Requests without the correct supporting documentation may not be approved. If the reason for your absence is not approved, you will be considered absent from that practical session.

It is your responsibility to submit an application and provide correct documentation.

  • Assessment extensions are only available for Prac 4 and 6. In addition to the 'Absence from Practical' form, you must apply for an extension of assessment due date.
  • This course is unable to provide an alternative session to attend.

If you require further assistance, please do not hesitate to contact the School - agriculture@enquire.uq.edu.au.

assessments.task_description:
Throughout the course you will be presented with lectures on eight topics in Plant Interactions. While these topics may seem distinct, they are linked via various molecular, biochemical, and ecological, pathways as plants do not interact with single individual microorganisms, but rather a complex of biotic and abiotic factors at any given time. To help develop your conceptual understanding of these lecture topics, you will prepare a mind map that builds connections between the individual lectures.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

learning_activities.topic:
Weekly lectures

Lectures will be held at weekly intervals and will be delivered by UQ academics and guest lecturers linked to plant interactions with their environment. Students can discuss these topics with the speakers in order to explore the topic in depth and foster their knowledge and expertise across the subdisciplines. The content of these lectures will be assessable in Mind Map.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Weekly lectures Lectures will be held at weekly intervals and will be delivered by UQ academics and guest lecturers linked to plant interactions with their environment. Students can discuss these topics with the speakers in order to explore the topic in depth and foster their knowledge and expertise across the subdisciplines. The content of these lectures will be assessable in Mind Map.

learning_activities.topic:
Practical classes

You will attend scheduled practical classes where you will isolate and identify a unique soil bacteria using microbiology, physiology, molecular biology and bioinformatic techniques. In each class, you will complete an assessment that will be delivered by blackboard and/or demonstrate a laboratory technique by the end of each practical session. Blackboard assessment may include a mix of multiple choice questions, short answer questions or uploading results from the practical session.

Practical Absence

If you are unable to complete your timetabled practical session because of circumstances beyond your control (e.g., illness) you must submit a practical absence request immediately accompanied by acceptable supporting documentation. 

A list of acceptable reasons and required supporting documentation is found at https://my.uq.edu.au/information-and-services/manage-my-program/exams-and-assessment/applying-assessment-extension?p=1#1   

Your request must be submitted prior to or on the day of the missed practical. The submission link can be found in the Learning Resources (Blackboard Original) or Course Resources (Blackboard Ultra) folder in your course Blackboard site. 

Requests without the correct supporting documentation may not be approved. If the reason for your absence is not approved, you will be considered as absent from that practical session.

It is your responsibility to submit an application and provide correct documentation.

This course is unable to provide an alternative session to attend.

All practical classes have an associated assessment item and you must apply for an extension of the assessment due date, noting that extensions are not available for assessments in Prac 1, 2, 3 and 5 .

If you require further assistance, please do not hesitate to contact the School - agriculture@enquire.uq.edu.au.
